sub_title: 👩🏻‍🔬 Animal Scientist 📅 Project Manager 🐓 Poultry Expert 🐷 Swine Expert 🧩 Puzzle Fan 🚶‍♀️ Avid Walker
summary:
I am an animal scientist with a keen interest in understanding animals, from why they behave in a certain way to how we should manage them in our production systems. I completed my M.Sc. in Animal Science at Wageningen University (The Netherlands) and received my PhD in Veterinary Medicine from University College Dublin (Ireland) and Teagasc – the Irish Agriculture and Food Development Authority. Since 2017, I work as a researcher and project manager at the University of Guelph, currently bridging the Centre for Genetic Improvement of Livestock and the Campbell Centre for the Study of Animal Welfare. 

Using my expertise in animal welfare, health, and behaviour in various species including swine, poultry, and, more recently, ruminants, I am looking to improve animal health and welfare, animal production, and livelihood of farmers. 

Some of the main research areas I work on include:

•	Investigation of tail lesions as indicators of pig welfare and health (collaboration with Teagasc, on-going)
•	Understanding the mechanisms and management of feather pecking in laying hens
•	Application of genomic selection in turkeys for health, welfare, efficiency and production traits
•	Integrating genomic approaches to improve dairy cattle resilience to enhance Canadian dairy industry sustainability

profile_positions.location: Department of Animal Biosciences, Ontario Agricultural College
profile_positions.description:
•	Process-driven and conscientious project manager motivated by empowering and supporting team members to complete tasks in a timely manner to meet project objectives

•	Coordinate research activities of co-investigators, collaborators and end users from international academic and industry partner organizations (team size 15 – 60 people)

•	Responsible for biannual scientific and quarterly financial reporting to stakeholders and funding agencies involved in 5 large-scale genomic projects with a combined budget of >20 million CAD

•	Manage communications between stakeholders via regular meetings and dissemination of project progress and results in scientific/technical publications, industry and conference presentations, and project website(s)  

Main projects include:
Project 1: ‘Application of genomic selection in turkeys for health, welfare, efficiency and production traits’ (2018 – present)

Project 2: ‘Integrating genomic approaches to improve dairy cattle resilience: A comprehensive goal to enhance Canadian dairy industry sustainability’ (2020 – present)
profile_positions.title: Project Manager | Sr. Research Associate

profile_positions.location: Department of Animal Biosciences, Ontario Agricultural College
profile_positions.description:
•	Provide specialized research knowledge in large-scale, multi-disciplinary projects from study design,  subject matter expertise in animal welfare, health & behaviour, data collection/management, statistical analysis, and mentoring of >50 students/postdocs
 
•	Dissemination of project findings in oral & written format to the scientific community, university and industry partners, funding agencies, stakeholders, and the general public. Includes media coverage, website development, and presentations at (inter)national scientific conferences & stakeholder meetings

Project 1: ‘Towards an understanding of beautiful feather cover’ (with Egg Farmers of Canada)
•	Devised a scoring tool for feather damage in chickens and practical feather pecking management plan
•	Liaised with 10 provincial egg boards and collaborated with >90 producers in risk factor surveys
•	Secured 120,000 CAD in funding (Mitacs Elevate) to direct a 2-yr epidemiological project on feather pecking

Project 2: ‘Understanding the underlying mechanisms of feather pecking’
•	Multi-disciplinary research on the role of the gut-brain-microbiome axis in feather pecking
•	Set-up of an organ bath apparatus to measure ex-vivo gut motility in feather pecking chickens 
•	Investigate impulsivity of peckers/non-peckers in an operant chamber

Project 3: ‘Impact of ammonia on the welfare of poultry’
•	Investigate the impact of ammonia and control measures in poultry production
•	Motivation testing of broilers and turkeys for different litter substrates
•	Research effects of different diets on poultry production, health, and performance in cognition tasks

Project 4: ‘Application of genomic selection in turkeys for health, welfare, efficiency & production traits’ (with Hybrid Turkeys)
•	Investigate feather corticosterone as a novel trait
•	Create inventory of management practices in turkey farms and identify risk factors for health traits

Project 5: ‘Integrating genomic approaches to improve dairy cattle resilience’
profile_positions.title: Animal Scientist | Postdoctoral Fellow

profile_positions.description:
Project 1: ‘Development of ante and post mortem meat inspection as a pig health and welfare diagnostic tool (PIGWELFIND)’ (2013 – 2017)

•	Contribute to a cross-border project including researchers from the Republic of Ireland and Northern-Ireland, UK for the development of ante and post mortem meat inspection as a pig health and welfare diagnostic tool (PIGWELFIND: ‘Pig Welfare Indicators’ or ‘Finding Pigs Well’) 
•	Investigate relationships between carcass tail lesions and management, respiratory disease, welfare and productivity on-farm to validate the use of tail lesions at meat inspection as iceberg indicators for pig health and welfare on-farm
•	Recruit and collaborate with >30 commercial farms and 3 abattoirs to coordinate people and resources for the execution of 5 research studies 
•	Participate in and report on stakeholder workshops with participating farmers, advisors, processors, meat inspectors, veterinary practitioners, and personnel with backgrounds in general animal health and welfare and food safety policy (24 stakeholders)
•	Results from this project were used to develop software for welfare and health diagnostic tools to be pilot tested in one of the largest abattoirs in Ireland, continued education modules to standardize meat inspector training, and  a risk assessment tool for on-farm tail biting currently being used as part of the Pig HealthCheck programme 

Involvement in other research projects with the Teagasc Pig Development Department

•	Development of a bio-economic stochastic simulation model for the pig industry
•	Investigation of respiratory disease on Irish pig farms
•	Relationship between antimicrobial usage and the welfare status of pigs
profile_positions.title: Swine Scientist | PhD Student, Veterinary Medicine

profile_positions.description:
•	Developed a brief of requirements based on behavioural needs of goats and participated in stakeholder workshops in the Go Goats! project to transfer knowledge to farmers to (re)design their farm and to increase sustainability throughout the production chain
•	Assist in various other project in the department of Innovation Processes and/or Animal Welfare by conducting literature reviews on farm animal welfare, participate in stakeholder workshops, meet with external clients, and write up of reports
•	Independently meet with an external client to scope and conduct a literature review, including write up of report, on the effects of a sloping floor on the welfare of beef cattle
profile_positions.title: Animal Scientist | Research Intern
